but at the office for people disability I had the best boss you could ever want.
And I was just sitting there pushing papers you know typing memos and you know so
that was an as exciting a job as I had hoped to have
you know and I know I could have moved around if I took some civil service tests and all that
but then my husband and I decided that we would move to New Jersey where he was living
. For the office for people with disabilities for
three years and we had gotten married and lived in Brooklyn for two two
and then. It was really hard to get around you know relying on
paratransit you know still you know it's Rockland County still the sidewalks are at a minimum
you know. And my husband was driving from my home to Long Island for his work you
know a lot of times are you know into New Jersey and I said you know it's crazy you know he
had a condo in New Jersey that he was renting out why don't we just move there
in their sidewalks and their transportation and you know so that's what we did
and I know eventually going to get to the disability awareness thing but there's a lot in
between. But.
So when I when I got down there of course now I couldn't work for rotten County anymore as you had to be a county
residents work there even though my boss so well you know maybe come in a couple times if we can
just take care of the paperwork but it was working and I couldn't get up there and you know
I don't tend to play by the rules you know they say you can't then I don't
write you know generally.
So today I was unemployed again and I decide to get into business enterprise
program you know run coffee shops and then and that was that was
interesting but it was really really hard and it just took
up all my time I had to rely on my husband a lot he was already busy with his work
and then all the paperwork and had to stay and I haven't actually had a B. e
ph stand right I had a first and then out to New Jersey which is down by three hole
and then I got a a bigger stand in Elizabeth and I look I like the
job I really did I would've been a great employee but I was not a good manager you know
if I was just somebody that was hired to work there.
I've done a bad job but making decisions hiring people firing people.
You know just watching you know I don't think I'm a business person you know I'm a great
great employee. So anyway so. Then we moved to New
York because New Jersey was a little bit too confining for me and my husband and
I will find ourselves going into New York from New Jersey to LA and we said well why don't we just live here
so I threw my husband he had a
he had a colleague that. Had got a job. With an
organization called Open Doors organization and this was after we moved to New
York so this came in really handy. He contacted my
husband to ask if he knew anyone that had a
disability and would be interested in that I also had experience in travel and
tourism for it and my husband said to my wife that's that's what she used to
do and so I sent in my resume and I got hired by
open doors and we did a year's worth of Amtrak trainings you
know.
Check was having a lot of problems and unfortunately I believe they still are having problems
with you know complaints the O.T. complaint
as to how they are assisting passengers with disabilities so for a year I would travel
up and down the East Coast you know from Miami to Boston and Albany and everywhere in between you know
training and track employees on the best way to assist passengers with
disabilities and how to integrate the A.P.A. and other federal
regulations like on section five o four
. Even you know five away you know the telecommunications you know the
Internet and all that. Yes you know to make sure that their their websites were accessible. So that's how I
started with the disability awareness you know and I can take everything I learned from
my record if I remember a video and from the office for people with disabilities
everything I learned you know working with people with all sorts of disabilities you
know dealing with the public's image of people with disabilities into this job
and also my airline experience because I knew what it was to be an
employee you know right handling people with disabilities and what it is now to be a
passenger with disability. So there
was that long a few cracks and I think I am.
Very interesting.
So what we don't you know if in terms of sort of thinking about
writing all these scenes if you could summarize what you want somebody to
to take away from listening to this story what are the important
things we want somebody to really learn from
what you've just told us
. Well but I think the public just
doesn't understand and by the public events including people who own businesses
and C.E.O.'s and they don't understand especially people who are
blind you know. The unemployment rate is like
astronomical. It's like over seventy percent of people who are blind
are unemployed and that's you know that's should be most of us
you know have. At least you know a high school education
you know. A lot of us have gone on to getting a bachelor's master's
some with Ph D.'s and they're all educated and were not given a
chance because they think that we can handle the positions are there you know what
can they do they can't see doesn't mean you can't think there's a need you can type Disney you can here
doesn't mean that you know I can be a loyal employee. You know. So I think that they should
just know that although all of us have a past
and we have experiences that we can take with us to another job. You
know. Also. I think there's a fear. Of people who are
born I don't know if they think are contagious you know are somehow
possessed by the downhaul Are we done something horrible in our lives that's made us go
blind but you know they don't have to be afraid of us. You know
you know we're approachable you know just you know ask
us what we need you know how do assist us that's one thing I find extremely
frustrating and I'm sure I did it when I could see you know I just go up and grab
somebody you know you come this way or you know. All of that you know
one of the big points we try to do in our Disability Awareness is you know don't assume what
people can do what they can do or how people want to be helped or even if they want to be helped you
know something you don't need it you know. I generally know where I'm going you know and if
I don't I I think you can tell I'm not trying you know I will ask you know for assistance
if I need it even if it means I have to stand in a military calling out today. Excuse
me you know I'll do that until somebody answers me. You know you can point to me you know you know you
know you might have anybody there but yeah you might think it's a little a little effect. I
get up and I need it. So I just think that
the perceptions need to change and they're. You know we're in a fragile
little eggs you know that need to be coddled or you know need to be sheltered
or hidden away or anything like that you know or people you know
we we have our capabilities and
which usually are more than our you know disability you
know where you know where you know just
treat us just treat us like you would want to be treated that wonderful
wonderful thank you so much Chris for coming in and sharing your story
with the true treatment for even I think a lot of people are rude
to ramble on too much.
I don't think so.
OK All right. Thank you
Glenn.
